awd_titl_txt: Characterization of Soft Fibrous Materials by MRI of Ultrasound-Induced Shear Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop a new experimental technique to measure the complex properties of soft, fibrous materials, non-invasively and non-destructively. Muscle, tendons, and brain tissue are examples of such materials, which are found throughout the human body and in nature. Artificial fiber-reinforced, soft biomaterials are increasingly being used in engineering applications. It is critical to know the mechanical properties of such materials, such as their stiffness and ability to store and dissipate energy. In this project, a novel combination of magnetic resonance imaging and high-intensity focused ultrasound will be used to comprehensively measure the mechanical properties of soft fibrous materials, either inside the human body, or in a controlled environment. Benefits to society include the improved ability to diagnose injury and fibrotic disease, to design and evaluate artificial tissues, and to perform accurate computer simulations of traumatic brain injury. In terms of workforce development, researchers from engineering and imaging will work together to build, test, and demonstrate the new technology. Graduate students will develop a set of sophisticated research skills that span these two disciplines. Leveraging a summer research program, as well as summer and weekend workshops, this project will provide training and research experience at the intersection of engineering and imaging to undergraduate students and middle/high school students from diverse backgrounds.

MR imaging of harmonic ultrasound-induced motion will be developed and applied to accurately measure the complex, anisotropic, nonlinear behavior of soft tissue and fibrous biomaterials. First, parameters of linear, anisotropic (transversely isotropic and orthotropic), viscoelastic models of fibrous soft biomaterials will be estimated from slow (pure transverse) and fast (quasi-transverse) shear waves. Shear waves, with varying propagation and polarization directions relative to material symmetry axes, will be induced by focused ultrasound and imaged by MRI in artificially aligned biomaterials, in muscle, and in white matter brain tissue. Shear moduli and tensile moduli will be estimated by fitting speeds of directionally-filtered plane waves to analytical expressions and simulated results. Second, the nonlinear behavior of fibrous, soft materials will be characterized. Two types of nonlinearity will be explored. (i) Nonlinearity in the small-strain regime, arising from strong material nonlinearity, will be measured by quantifying the higher harmonic components of wave motion.  (ii) Nonlinear, large-strain behavior will be characterized by imaging slow and fast shear waves superimposed on large deformations. This novel approach is expected to provide comprehensive characterization of anisotropy and nonlinearity, with unprecedented resolution, throughout these increasingly-important materials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

This project was aimed at improving the ability to non-invasively characterize the mechanical behavior (stiffness or softness) of soft tissue, using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In particular, the main goal was to use MR imaging of waves in the tissue to estimate properties of materials that are stiffer in some directions than in others. Materials in which stiffness depends on direction are known as "anisotropic" materials; they typically include fibers that provide increased resistance in one dominant direction.

This MRI-based technique requires a way to generate waves in tissue. In this project we developed a method to use focused ultrasound to generate shear waves that propagate outwardly from the focal point. The focused ultrasound must be turned on and off, or modulated, to create waves.

First, we showed that we could estimate mechanical stiffness in different directions by estimating the wave speeds in different directions, and working backwards ("inverting" the data) to get the properties.

Second, we developed a ?machine-learning? approach to estimate these direction-dependent properties. Machine learning is a method in which a computer algorithm learns patterns in data and can associate these patterns with specific material properties. We used a method based on ?neural networks?, which are computer algorithms built to try to mimic the human brain?s ability to recognize patterns.

Third, we worked with collaborators to develop a general tool to estimate direction-dependent material parameters by simulating the system, and changing the inputs to the simulation until the simulated field closely matched the wave field in the experiment.

Finally, we developed an approach to 3D-printing soft materials with direction-dependent properties using composite materials with a stiffer gel lattice embedded in a softer gel. These artificial anisotropic materials are being used to evaluate and improve our stiffness estimation methods.

Broader impact

Broader impact was achieved by training both graduate and undergraduate students, who will enter the workforce with experience in characterizing the mechanical behavior of biomaterials, and using imaging to understand biomechanics. Broader impact was also achieved by outreach to high-school and middle-school age students from St. Louis, using hands-on demonstrations by Washington University students to engage the younger students.

The project has provided research training and professional development opportunities to three (1F, 1 URM) graduate students (F=female, URM = member of under-represented group): Charlotte Guertler (PhD in ME 2019; F); Zuoxian Hou (PhD in ME 2021); Preston Bailey (MSME 2021;URM).

The project has provided research training and professional development opportunities to ten (5F, 1URM) undergraduate students: (1) Jake Ireland; (2) Alexa Panrudkevich (F); (3) Julia Rifkin (F); (4) Jiahao Wei; (5) Payal Hukeri (F); (6) Devin Williamson (URM); (7) Justin Wan; (8) Keshav Kailash; (9) Maeve Lomax (F); (10) Annie Mascot (F). Of these. Three (Wei, Williamson, Kailash) are currently in engineering PhD programs, and two others (Rifkin, Panrudkevich) are pursuing either MS or MD degrees.

Demonstrations of waves in soft biomaterials (Jello, e.g.) were used in numerous outreach events to introduce middle-school and high school students to engineering.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2021
Modified by: Philip V Bayly
